common_confusions: Do not generalize suffixing behavior from singular reflexives to plurals; plurals place possessive before ɖókui.
Tonal inversion in suffixed singular reflexives is a phonological effect, not an orthographic accident.
Do not equate Ewe governance titles with Twi/Akan equivalents unless text explicitly compares them.
Fiagã (Ewe paramount chief) has different functions than Akan Ohene; use only Ewe curriculum definitions.
strict_rules: Reflexives must be formed using ɖókui combined with possessive pronouns exactly as shown in Lesson XVII (BASIC_EWE_2nd_ed.pdf, p.149).
For plural reflexives, place the possessive pronoun before ɖókui (BASIC_EWE_2nd_ed.pdf, p.149).
Serial verb constructions should be treated as multi-verb sequences within a single clause, sharing tense/aspect as shown in the curriculum.
Use Ewe governance terminology exactly as defined in the cultural PDF (Dekɔnudziɖuɖu, Fiagã, Dufia, Tofia, Hlɔ̃tatɔ, Fiatɔwo).

restrictions.reason: Governance titles and hierarchies must be defined exactly as they appear in curriculum. Fiagã > Dufia > Tofia hierarchy is specific to Ewe systems.
Functions of governance officials (Fiagã, Dufia, Hlɔ̃tatɔ, Fiatɔwo) must follow curriculum exactly. Do not invent functions not mentioned.
Family structure governance (vifofo, ƒometatɔ, hlɔ̃tatɔ) must reflect Ewe patrilineal/matrilineal context as specified.
The curriculum describes kingmakers (Fiatɔwo) and their general role but does not detail secret selection processes. Do not fabricate rite-specific procedures.
Deity names and deities must be taken only from the curriculum examples. Do not invent deity names or attributes not mentioned in the Ewe PDF.
Do not explain hidden spiritual beliefs or secret aspects of deity worship. Limit responses to public curriculum definitions.

restrictions.reason: The curriculum describes general phases (before/during/after) and some activities but does not detail all ritual procedures or secrets. Do not hallucinate ritual steps.
Gbɔtowɔwɔ (girls' rites) must be described using only the three-phase structure given in curriculum: do ŋgɔ na kɔnua wɔwɔ, kɔnua wɔwɔ ŋutɔ, kɔnua wɔwɔ megbe.
Curriculum does not include secret or private aspects of initiation. Refuse questions about hidden ceremonies or restricted knowledge.
Libation structure (Nuʋuʋu, Tsia ƒoƒo ɖi, Taƒoƒo) must follow curriculum exactly. Gender restrictions on who can perform libation should be noted as curriculum states.
While significance is explained, curriculum does not provide detailed methods for composing dirges. Do not provide specific poetic formulas not in the text.
